class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (PDF-3 MB)</span></a></div></div></div></div> <p><strong>Year after year,</strong> majorities of participants in our research on social technologies have reported that their organizations use such tools in their business and that they see measurable benefits as a result—and according to our latest survey, these patterns continue.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote1" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="b59af0bf-b0d8-4780-b65c-0e4f377646ff" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">1</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span class="tooltip" id="footnote1"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">1.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="b59af0bf-b0d8-4780-b65c-0e4f377646ff"><span></span>
The online survey was in the field from June 11 to June 21, 2013, and garnered responses from 2,609 executives representing the full range of regions, industries, company sizes, tenures, and functional specialties. To adjust for differences in response rates, the data are weighted by the contribution of each respondent’s nation to global GDP.
</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  For the first time, though, the percentages of companies adopting these technologies and reaping related benefits seem to have plateaued. In 2013, 82 percent say their companies use at least one tool in their business (compared with 83 percent in 2012 and 72 percent in 2011), and 87 percent of those executives report at least one measurable benefit (compared with 90 percent the previous two years).</p>

<p> Nevertheless, the most recent results suggest that there are considerable opportunities for further adoption, within companies and with customers and business partners. They also shed new light on what the companies that reap higher-than-average benefits are doing right. According to executives, the organizations deriving the greatest internal <em>and</em> external benefits from using social tools (what we call “fully networked” enterprises) implement specific practices that support organizational changes, such as role modeling and building capabilities, more comprehensively than all others. The fully networked organizations are also more likely to establish formal strategies around the usage of social tools; taken together, these practices and strategies create an environment that’s better suited to achieving value from technologies. While there are still significant constraints on realizing the full potential of these tools,<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote2" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="66e60509-3ed9-4b2a-a183-292872c99a54" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">2</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span class="tooltip" id="footnote2"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">2.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="66e60509-3ed9-4b2a-a183-292872c99a54"><span></span>
According to the McKinsey Global Institute, the implementation of social technologies could improve the productivity of know­ledge workers by 20 to 25 percent. For more, see <a class="footnote-innerlink"><em>The social economy: Unlocking value and productivity through social technologies</em></a>, McKinsey Global Institute, July 2012.
</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  all organizations could be doing more. The responses affirm that companies have much more to gain from social technologies and that adopting some key practices can create measurable advantages.</p>

<h2>Adoption plateaus, with room to grow</h2> 

<p> The shares of companies using some kind of social technology in their business, overall and on mobile devices, is high but leveling out. Eighty-two percent of respondents say their companies use at least one tool (compared with 83 percent in 2012), and 67 percent report the use of at least one tool on mobile (compared with 65 percent in 2012). The most commonly used tools—videoconferencing, social networking, and collaborative editing—are the same as we saw the previous year (Exhibit 1).</p><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Videoconferencing and social networks are used most often in the business.</div></h5></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/organizing%20the%20networked%20enterprise%20for%20change/svgmobt33web202013exhibit1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/organizing%20the%20networked%20enterprise%20for%20change/svgmobt33web202013exhibit1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p> Still, there’s room to improve the percentages of employees who use these tools. Four in ten respondents say at least half of their companies’ employees use social networking for work, but less than 30 percent say the same about all other technologies. There are also opportunities to increase external use: 76 percent of executives say their companies use social technologies with customers, but on average their companies interact with only 38 percent of customers via social tools. Meanwhile, just 44 percent report using social technologies to communicate with partners, suppliers, or outside experts.</p>

<p> A vast majority of respondents continue to cite business benefits,<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote3" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="b435788c-bc42-43a0-bdf2-11ca91afa576" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">3</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span class="tooltip" id="footnote3"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">3.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="b435788c-bc42-43a0-bdf2-11ca91afa576"><span></span>
In the 2013 survey, 87 percent of respondents say their organizations see at least one measurable benefit from social tools, roughly the same share as in the previous three surveys.
</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  while the mix of enterprises where executives report higher-than-average benefits, either internal or external, is consistent with 2012 results. One-fifth of companies qualify as fully networked organizations (Exhibit 2), those reaping the highest improvements in benefits from their technology use with internal and external stakeholders.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote4" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="a7b3f887-d698-4909-9830-be1ff5260617" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">4</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span class="tooltip" id="footnote4"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">4.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="a7b3f887-d698-4909-9830-be1ff5260617"><span></span>
After the 2012 survey, we reported that 10 percent of respondents worked at fully networked organizations and 29 percent at externally networked enterprises. These figures resulted from a methodology that was inconsistent with what had been used in previous years, and they have been revised accordingly. See Jacques Bughin and Michael Chui, “<a class="footnote-innerlink">Evolution of the networked enterprise: McKinsey Global Survey results</a>,” March 2013.
</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  Similar shares of organizations as in 2012 qualify as “internally networked” and “developing,” and a slightly larger share are now “externally networked” (which see outsize benefits from social interactions with customers, partners, and suppliers).<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote5" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="48f2847b-8d45-4a57-b6f7-9fa16b05337a" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">5</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span class="tooltip" id="footnote5"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">5.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="48f2847b-8d45-4a57-b6f7-9fa16b05337a"><span></span>
Based on the average level of improvements in reported business benefits, internally networked organizations see outsize benefits from their social interactions among employees, while at developing organizations, respon­dents report lower-than-average improvements across all social interactions at their organizations.
</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  On specific benefits, executives cite roughly the same improvements from their technology use as they did in 2012 (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>One-fifth of organizations are ‘fully networked’ and see outsize benefits from internal and external social interactions.</div></h5></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/organizing%20the%20networked%20enterprise%20for%20change/svgmobt33web202013exhibit2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/organizing%20the%20networked%20enterprise%20for%20change/svgmobt33web202013exhibit2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Implementing the tools of change</h2> 

<p> Yet even at the fully networked companies, executives indicate that social tools offer further opportunities. Their responses help explain the difference between companies reaping the greatest benefits and all others: thoughtful application of the key tactics of organizational change and of strategies for using social tools.</p>

<p> Effective use of technologies is an organizational transformation in its own right that, in our experience, requires a shift in user mind-sets and behaviors. These shifts are best achieved through the “influence model,” a guideline for sustainable change that includes four key practices: using aligned systems and structures to reinforce change, role modeling, building capabilities, and fostering understanding of and commitment to change (see sidebar, “More on the influence model”).</p><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>More on the influence model</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Based on four key principles, the influence model was designed to address the shifts in mind-sets and behaviors that, in our experience, are a prerequisite for successful organizational change—whether it’s taking advantage of new social technologies in the business or a large-scale redesign of the organization’s overarching structure.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote8" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="a1d59407-17d0-4d91-a37f-049219615c0a" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">1</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span class="tooltip" id="footnote8"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">1.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="a1d59407-17d0-4d91-a37f-049219615c0a"><span></span>
For more, see Carolyn Aiken and Scott Keller, “<a class="footnote-innerlink">The irrational side of change management</a>,” <em>McKinsey Quarterly</em>, April 2009.
</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  The most effective change programs incorporate complementary, consistent actions based on the following principles, which we tested for in the survey:</p>

<ul class="bulletList">
<li><em>Aligned systems and structures.</em> Companies can reinforce change with formal mechanisms by adjusting organizational structure and processes to align with the changes, setting performance goals for individuals and the organization as a whole, and motivating people to perform, based on the new, changed vision. The underlying assumption is that employees will change their behavior if the systems reinforce the desired change.</li>

<li><em>Role modeling and leadership.</em> Company leaders can role model changes by setting examples of desired behaviors in day-to-day interactions, enlisting help from influential stakeholders to shape behaviors, and ensuring that teams’ work and interactions are in line with the changes. The underlying assumption is that employees will change their behavior if they see their leaders behaving differently.</li>

<li><em>Capability building.</em> Companies can develop talent and skills by evaluating the performance of employees in key positions, reducing attrition of high-performing individuals, and offering a range of development and training opportunities that reflect the changes and the new skills employees might need to perform as a result. The underlying assumption is that employees will change their behavior if they have the skills to behave in the new way.</li>

<li><em>Understanding and commitment.</em> Companies can foster understanding and commitment by articulating key elements of the “change story” to all levels of the organization, making sure employees know why changes needed to happen and how they will be supported, and tracking the story to make sure it is relevant to the overall agenda and people’s day-to-day work. The underlying assumption is that employees will change their behavior if they know what they need to change—and if they want to do it.</li></ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p> The 2013 survey included questions to measure the link between the four practices and companies’ social-technology use. As the model would suggest, the executives from fully networked enterprises report that their organizations implement each of the practices more intensively than all other companies do (Exhibit 4). Additionally, the more practices a company has introduced in an intensive way, the likelier it is to be fully networked and reap outsize internal and external benefits (Exhibit 5).</p><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Fully networked companies most rigorously implement the actions that support organizational change.</div></h5></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/organizing%20the%20networked%20enterprise%20for%20change/svgmobt33web202013exhibit4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/organizing%20the%20networked%20enterprise%20for%20change/svgmobt33web202013exhibit4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div> <div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>The more intensive pursuit of change activities links to greater benefits from social tools.</div></h5></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/organizing%20the%20networked%20enterprise%20for%20change/svgmobt33web202013exhibit5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/organizing%20the%20networked%20enterprise%20for%20change/svgmobt33web202013exhibit5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p> At fully networked organizations, 65 percent of respondents say employees in at least two levels of their companies are role modeling effective use of social tools (compared with 37 percent at developing organizations), and these organizations are the most likely to have people role modeling in most positions in the enterprise (Exhibit 6). Fully networked organizations are also the most likely to reinforce change through systems and structures: 46 percent of executives at these companies say tools are highly integrated into employees’ day-to-day work, while just 19 percent say so at the developing organizations that are not seeing any outsize benefits.</p><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 6</span></div><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>More frontline employees, middle managers, and senior executives at fully networked companies role model the use of social tools.</div></h5></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/organizing%20the%20networked%20enterprise%20for%20change/svgmobt33web202013exhibit6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/organizing%20the%20networked%20enterprise%20for%20change/svgmobt33web202013exhibit6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p> On capability building, the share of respondents at fully networked companies who report the use of three or more methods to train employees on social tools (out of eight we asked about) is nearly twice the share at developing or externally networked organizations. To measure commitment to change, the survey asked which of four related statements describe respondents’ companies; 46 percent of fully networked executives agree with at least two statements,<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote6" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="71c3305c-4bab-4496-b6df-cf5cd2720f85" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">6</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span class="tooltip" id="footnote6"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">6.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="71c3305c-4bab-4496-b6df-cf5cd2720f85"><span></span>
The four statements related to understanding and commitment were as follows: “The use of social technolo­gies helps my company and its leaders co­create and share our mission and vision,” “Employees need to share information with each other and are rewarded for doing so,” “My company helps employees understand how social technologies can affect their role or their work,” and “Because of the company’s efforts to foster understanding of social technologies, employees believe they can do their job better using these tools.”
</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  compared with just one-fifth of those at developing companies.</p>

<p> Beyond the influence model, companies’ deliberate strategy decisions matter as well. According to executives, fully networked enterprises are nearly twice as likely as developing enterprises to have a formal company-wide strategy for social-technology use. What’s more, the fully networked respondents are three times more likely than those at developing companies to say three or more of their individual functions (out of seven) have formal social strategies.</p>

<h2>More organizational barriers to overcome</h2> 

<p> Executives expect that in the coming years, social technologies could enable large changes in organizational and management processes. But respondents still identify large gaps between the possibility for change at their own companies and at a company with no constraints on its technology use. As in the past two surveys, respondents believe that at their organizations, scanning the external environment, finding new ideas, and managing projects are the processes with the greatest potential to change through the use of social tools.</p>

<p> We took a closer look at executives who responded in 2011, when we first asked about future organizational changes, and who work for companies that are now reaping more benefits from social technologies than two years earlier.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote7" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="d7067895-64ab-43a7-a089-e3a707776baf" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">7</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span class="tooltip" id="footnote7"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">7.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="d7067895-64ab-43a7-a089-e3a707776baf"><span></span>
For example, these would include organizations that fell into the “developing” category in 2011—based on respondents’ reporting of the scope of benefits their companies received from their use of social tech­nol­ogies—that are now either internally, externally, or fully networked.
</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  Compared with their responses in 2011, these respondents are now less likely to expect their own organizations’ processes (with the exception of project management) will evolve due to their use of social tools. What’s more, the gaps between potential process changes at their own companies and at hypothetical organizations without constraints have grown since 2011. There are some possible explanations for the growing disparity—for example, that executives are finding these changes difficult to implement, that changes take time to translate into measurable value, and that companies that have made strides have only scratched the surface, so executives believe that much more change is possible.</p>

<h2>Looking ahead</h2> 

<ul class="bulletList">
<li><em>Focus on organizational levers.</em> To continue reaping real benefits from social tools—and to use them even more rigorously, to capture more value—companies at all stages of usage will have to back their deployment of the tools with the practices that support organizational change. In doing so, companies should examine how each element of the influence model can be best applied to enhance the value they capture from their use of social technologies.</li>

<li><em>Formalize strategy.</em> The fully networked organizations seeing the greatest social-related improvements are also the most likely to have thoughtful, comprehensive strategies for technology use. Given the experimental nature of social technologies, it’s not possible (or even advisable) to think through all of their applications. But companies can still plan for their use of these tools, decide how to integrate them into important business problems, and determine where they can add value as early as possible.</li>

<li><em>Set high aspirations.</em> While some companies are reaping the full benefits that social tools offer, many others should aim higher. Most companies could profit by reconsidering what’s possible beyond their current use of technologies. Managers may find that making small strides in increasing value can result in a whole set of potential benefits they did not see initially—whether it’s making specific processes more efficient, improving their workers’ overall productivity, or changing the competitive landscape in their industries.</li></ul>

The companies reaping the greatest benefits are especially good at implementing organizational practices that enhance these tools\u0026#8217; value, but even they have room to grow."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2014-03-01T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]] \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYear after year,\u003c/strong\u003e majorities of participants in our research on social technologies have reported that their organizations use such tools in their business and that they see measurable benefits as a result\u0026#8212;and according to our latest survey, these patterns continue.\u003ca class=\"link-footnote\" rel=\"#footnote1\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"return false;\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e1\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan id=\"footnote1\" class=\"tooltip\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e1.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nThe online survey was in the field from June 11 to June 21, 2013, and garnered responses from 2,609 executives representing the full range of regions, industries, company sizes, tenures, and functional specialties. To adjust for differences in response rates, the data are weighted by the contribution of each respondent\u0026#8217;s nation to global GDP.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e For the first time, though, the percentages of companies adopting these technologies and reaping related benefits seem to have plateaued. In 2013, 82 percent say their companies use at least one tool in their business (compared with 83 percent in 2012 and 72 percent in 2011), and 87 percent of those executives report at least one measurable benefit (compared with 90 percent the previous two years).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e Nevertheless, the most recent results suggest that there are considerable opportunities for further adoption, within companies and with customers and business partners. They also shed new light on what the companies that reap higher-than-average benefits are doing right. According to executives, the organizations deriving the greatest internal \u003cem\u003eand\u003c/em\u003e external benefits from using social tools (what we call \u0026#8220;fully networked\u0026#8221; enterprises) implement specific practices that support organizational changes, such as role modeling and building capabilities, more comprehensively than all others. The fully networked organizations are also more likely to establish formal strategies around the usage of social tools; taken together, these practices and strategies create an environment that\u0026#8217;s better suited to achieving value from technologies. While there are still significant constraints on realizing the full potential of these tools,\u003ca class=\"link-footnote\" rel=\"#footnote2\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"return false;\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e2\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan id=\"footnote2\" class=\"tooltip\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e2.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nAccording to the McKinsey Global Institute, the implementation of social technologies could improve the productivity of know\u0026#173;ledge workers by 20 to 25 percent. For more, see \u003ca href=\"/insights/high_tech_telecoms_internet/the_social_economy\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe social economy: Unlocking value and productivity through social technologies\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, McKinsey Global Institute, July 2012.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e all organizations could be doing more. The responses affirm that companies have much more to gain from social technologies and that adopting some key practices can create measurable advantages.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eAdoption plateaus, with room to grow\u003c/h2\u003e \n\n\u003cp\u003e The shares of companies using some kind of social technology in their business, overall and on mobile devices, is high but leveling out. Eighty-two percent of respondents say their companies use at least one tool (compared with 83 percent in 2012), and 67 percent report the use of at least one tool on mobile (compared with 65 percent in 2012). The most commonly used tools\u0026#8212;videoconferencing, social networking, and collaborative editing\u0026#8212;are the same as we saw the previous year (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e[[exhibit 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e Still, there\u0026#8217;s room to improve the percentages of employees who use these tools. Four in ten respondents say at least half of their companies\u0026#8217; employees use social networking for work, but less than 30 percent say the same about all other technologies. There are also opportunities to increase external use: 76 percent of executives say their companies use social technologies with customers, but on average their companies interact with only 38 percent of customers via social tools. Meanwhile, just 44 percent report using social technologies to communicate with partners, suppliers, or outside experts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e A vast majority of respondents continue to cite business benefits,\u003ca class=\"link-footnote\" rel=\"#footnote3\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"return false;\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e3\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan id=\"footnote3\" class=\"tooltip\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e3.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nIn the 2013 survey, 87 percent of respondents say their organizations see at least one measurable benefit from social tools, roughly the same share as in the previous three surveys.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e while the mix of enterprises where executives report higher-than-average benefits, either internal or external, is consistent with 2012 results. One-fifth of companies qualify as fully networked organizations (Exhibit 2), those reaping the highest improvements in benefits from their technology use with internal and external stakeholders.\u003ca class=\"link-footnote\" rel=\"#footnote4\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"return false;\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e4\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan id=\"footnote4\" class=\"tooltip\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e4.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nAfter the 2012 survey, we reported that 10 percent of respondents worked at fully networked organizations and 29 percent at externally networked enterprises. These figures resulted from a methodology that was inconsistent with what had been used in previous years, and they have been revised accordingly. See Jacques Bughin and Michael Chui, \u0026#8220;\u003ca href=\"/insights/business_technology/evolution_of_the_networked_enterprise_mckinsey_global_survey_results\"\u003eEvolution of the networked enterprise: McKinsey Global Survey results\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026#8221; March 2013.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Similar shares of organizations as in 2012 qualify as \u0026#8220;internally networked\u0026#8221; and \u0026#8220;developing,\u0026#8221; and a slightly larger share are now \u0026#8220;externally networked\u0026#8221; (which see outsize benefits from social interactions with customers, partners, and suppliers).\u003ca class=\"link-footnote\" rel=\"#footnote5\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"return false;\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e5\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan id=\"footnote5\" class=\"tooltip\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e5.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nBased on the average level of improvements in reported business benefits, internally networked organizations see outsize benefits from their social interactions among employees, while at developing organizations, respon\u0026#173;dents report lower-than-average improvements across all social interactions at their organizations.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e On specific benefits, executives cite roughly the same improvements from their technology use as they did in 2012 (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 2]] [[exhibit 3]]\n\n\u003ch2\u003eImplementing the tools of change\u003c/h2\u003e \n\n\u003cp\u003e Yet even at the fully networked companies, executives indicate that social tools offer further opportunities. Their responses help explain the difference between companies reaping the greatest benefits and all others: thoughtful application of the key tactics of organizational change and of strategies for using social tools.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e Effective use of technologies is an organizational transformation in its own right that, in our experience, requires a shift in user mind-sets and behaviors. These shifts are best achieved through the \u0026#8220;influence model,\u0026#8221; a guideline for sustainable change that includes four key practices: using aligned systems and structures to reinforce change, role modeling, building capabilities, and fostering understanding of and commitment to change (see sidebar, \u0026#8220;More on the influence model\u0026#8221;).\u003c/p\u003e[[sidebar sidebar]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e The 2013 survey included questions to measure the link between the four practices and companies\u0026#8217; social-technology use. As the model would suggest, the executives from fully networked enterprises report that their organizations implement each of the practices more intensively than all other companies do (Exhibit 4). Additionally, the more practices a company has introduced in an intensive way, the likelier it is to be fully networked and reap outsize internal and external benefits (Exhibit 5).\u003c/p\u003e[[exhibit 4]] [[exhibit 5]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e At fully networked organizations, 65 percent of respondents say employees in at least two levels of their companies are role modeling effective use of social tools (compared with 37 percent at developing organizations), and these organizations are the most likely to have people role modeling in most positions in the enterprise (Exhibit 6). Fully networked organizations are also the most likely to reinforce change through systems and structures: 46 percent of executives at these companies say tools are highly integrated into employees\u0026#8217; day-to-day work, while just 19 percent say so at the developing organizations that are not seeing any outsize benefits.\u003c/p\u003e[[exhibit 6]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e On capability building, the share of respondents at fully networked companies who report the use of three or more methods to train employees on social tools (out of eight we asked about) is nearly twice the share at developing or externally networked organizations. To measure commitment to change, the survey asked which of four related statements describe respondents\u0026#8217; companies; 46 percent of fully networked executives agree with at least two statements,\u003ca class=\"link-footnote\" rel=\"#footnote6\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"return false;\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e6\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan id=\"footnote6\" class=\"tooltip\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e6.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nThe four statements related to understanding and commitment were as follows: \u0026#8220;The use of social technolo\u0026#173;gies helps my company and its leaders co\u0026#173;create and share our mission and vision,\u0026#8221; \u0026#8220;Employees need to share information with each other and are rewarded for doing so,\u0026#8221; \u0026#8220;My company helps employees understand how social technologies can affect their role or their work,\u0026#8221; and \u0026#8220;Because of the company\u0026#8217;s efforts to foster understanding of social technologies, employees believe they can do their job better using these tools.\u0026#8221;\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e compared with just one-fifth of those at developing companies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e Beyond the influence model, companies\u0026#8217; deliberate strategy decisions matter as well. According to executives, fully networked enterprises are nearly twice as likely as developing enterprises to have a formal company-wide strategy for social-technology use. What\u0026#8217;s more, the fully networked respondents are three times more likely than those at developing companies to say three or more of their individual functions (out of seven) have formal social strategies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eMore organizational barriers to overcome\u003c/h2\u003e \n\n\u003cp\u003e Executives expect that in the coming years, social technologies could enable large changes in organizational and management processes. But respondents still identify large gaps between the possibility for change at their own companies and at a company with no constraints on its technology use. As in the past two surveys, respondents believe that at their organizations, scanning the external environment, finding new ideas, and managing projects are the processes with the greatest potential to change through the use of social tools.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e We took a closer look at executives who responded in 2011, when we first asked about future organizational changes, and who work for companies that are now reaping more benefits from social technologies than two years earlier.\u003ca class=\"link-footnote\" rel=\"#footnote7\" href=\"#\" onclick=\"return false;\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e7\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan id=\"footnote7\" class=\"tooltip\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e7.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nFor example, these would include organizations that fell into the \u0026#8220;developing\u0026#8221; category in 2011\u0026#8212;based on respondents\u0026#8217; reporting of the scope of benefits their companies received from their use of social tech\u0026#173;nol\u0026#173;ogies\u0026#8212;that are now either internally, externally, or fully networked.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Compared with their responses in 2011, these respondents are now less likely to expect their own organizations\u0026#8217; processes (with the exception of project management) will evolve due to their use of social tools. What\u0026#8217;s more, the gaps between potential process changes at their own companies and at hypothetical organizations without constraints have grown since 2011. There are some possible explanations for the growing disparity\u0026#8212;for example, that executives are finding these changes difficult to implement, that changes take time to translate into measurable value, and that companies that have made strides have only scratched the surface, so executives believe that much more change is possible.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eLooking ahead\u003c/h2\u003e \n\n\u003cul class=\"bulletList\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFocus on organizational levers.\u003c/em\u003e To continue reaping real benefits from social tools\u0026#8212;and to use them even more rigorously, to capture more value\u0026#8212;companies at all stages of usage will have to back their deployment of the tools with the practices that support organizational change. In doing so, companies should examine how each element of the influence model can be best applied to enhance the value they capture from their use of social technologies.\u003c/li\u003e\n\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFormalize strategy.\u003c/em\u003e The fully networked organizations seeing the greatest social-related improvements are also the most likely to have thoughtful, comprehensive strategies for technology use. Given the experimental nature of social technologies, it\u0026#8217;s not possible (or even advisable) to think through all of their applications. But companies can still plan for their use of these tools, decide how to integrate them into important business problems, and determine where they can add value as early as possible.\u003c/li\u003e\n\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSet high aspirations.\u003c/em\u003e While some companies are reaping the full benefits that social tools offer, many others should aim higher. Most companies could profit by reconsidering what\u0026#8217;s possible beyond their current use of technologies. Managers may find that making small strides in increasing value can result in a whole set of potential benefits they did not see initially\u0026#8212;whether it\u0026#8217;s making specific processes more efficient, improving their workers\u0026#8217; overall productivity, or changing the competitive landscape in their industries.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE 2009.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e The most effective change programs incorporate complementary, consistent actions based on the following principles, which we tested for in the survey:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul class=\"bulletList\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAligned systems and structures.\u003c/em\u003e Companies can reinforce change with formal mechanisms by adjusting organizational structure and processes to align with the changes, setting performance goals for individuals and the organization as a whole, and motivating people to perform, based on the new, changed vision. The underlying assumption is that employees will change their behavior if the systems reinforce the desired change.\u003c/li\u003e\n\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRole modeling and leadership.\u003c/em\u003e Company leaders can role model changes by setting examples of desired behaviors in day-to-day interactions, enlisting help from influential stakeholders to shape behaviors, and ensuring that teams\u0026#8217; work and interactions are in line with the changes. The underlying assumption is that employees will change their behavior if they see their leaders behaving differently.\u003c/li\u003e\n\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCapability building.\u003c/em\u003e Companies can develop talent and skills by evaluating the performance of employees in key positions, reducing attrition of high-performing individuals, and offering a range of development and training opportunities that reflect the changes and the new skills employees might need to perform as a result. The underlying assumption is that employees will change their behavior if they have the skills to behave in the new way.\u003c/li\u003e\n\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUnderstanding and commitment.\u003c/em\u003e Companies can foster understanding and commitment by articulating key elements of the \u0026#8220;change story\u0026#8221; to all levels of the organization, making sure employees know why changes needed to happen and how they will be supported, and tracking the story to make sure it is relevant to the overall agenda and people\u0026#8217;s day-to-day work. The underlying assumption is that employees will change their behavior if they know what they need to change\u0026#8212;and if they want to do
